instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15” Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.BKL_SW: What is BKL_SW? BKL_SW means “BACKLIGHT SWITCH” – DC to DC boost circuits increase voltage by putting a lower voltage, like 8 volts, through an inductor. On the other side of the inductor, it is switched to ground rapidly - on this side, you will end up with an increased voltage as a result of the switching. BKL_SW usually refers to the pin on the LED driver that is attached to the inductor. .
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A gpu issues
threads.message:
I have a MBP here.

History: Previously going into kernel panic and having graphic issues. Customer done work around <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> with bad results - components moved - some connections bridged etc - its been fixed now.

Machine does boot with image but no backlight. Upon testing some voltages

I can see <SIGNAL>GPU_3</SIGNAL>.3, IFPX IOVDD, GPUVCORE are all outputting 3.3v???? how is this possible?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A gpu issues
threads.message: Voltage on L8930 is 3V? No way!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A gpu issues
threads.message:
i was measuring off <CAPACITOR>C8930</CAPACITOR>
its now at .9v

man i was on idiot mode yesterday :(

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A gpu issues
threads.message:
Okay - non lazy version: Basically i got video out. No backlight. I can see apple logo with torch. Also external display is present.

here are the voltages

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.62v
pp3v42 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 3.34v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5.06v
pin 1 on lcd connector 0v

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_BKL</SIGNAL> 0v

<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> 100mV
<SIGNAL>BKL_SW</SIGNAL> 80mV

<CAPACITOR>C9711</CAPACITOR> 3.3v present
<CAPACITOR>C9710</CAPACITOR> 5v present

f9700 12.6v on both side

<TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> getting 12.6v on pin 3 and 4 but im getting 0v on 1-2-5-6

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A gpu issues
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A gpu issues
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 36927"]<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> present? PRAM reset done?[/QUOTE]

pram done - nothing on <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>

according to what customer said he only worked around the <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>. now the guy doesnt have microscope he bridged a connection and some components were removed. I will re-check this area. Duke do you think it could be something in this area that is affecting smc in anyway? or smc straight out screwed?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A gpu issues
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8900</CHIP> has nothing to do with backlight if all rails it produces are present.

<SIGNAL>EG_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> present? It could be a MUX or GPU problem if hot air was applied to the area. You are checking these voltages with an LCD connected I hope.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A gpu issues
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 36978"]<CHIP>U8900</CHIP> has nothing to do with backlight if all rails it produces are present.

<SIGNAL>EG_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> present? It could be a MUX or GPU problem if hot air was applied to the area. You are checking these voltages with an LCD connected I hope.[/QUOTE]

forgive me i was teting without LCd connector :eek:
with lcd connector connector <SIGNAL>EG_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> present

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A gpu issues
threads.message: PWOARRRRRR. found problem. pin 1 was bent on lcd connector so far back. only spotted under microscope. full working now thanks for ur help duke legendary as always.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A gpu issues
threads.message: You should have measures 50V at pin 1 from the start indicating an open backlight circuit.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A gpu issues
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 37037"]You should have measures 50V at pin 1 from the start indicating an open backlight circuit. [/QUOTE]

yeh my bad thanks
